executable.title: Transforms
executable.description:
This module is used for creating and editing transformation matrices.
Transformation nodes are used in Slicer to define spacial relationships between different nodes (such as volumes, models, fiducials, ROI's, or other Transform nodes) or between the nodes and the global RAS space.
You can establish these relations by moving nodes from the Transformable list to the Transformed list or by dragging the nodes under the Transformation nodes in the Data module.

parameter.label: Active Transform
parameter.description: Select the transform node to display, control and edit.

parameter.label: Transform to parent:
parameter.description: Description of the transform that is applied to transform points to the coordinate system of the parent transform node.

parameter.label: Transform from parent:
parameter.description: Description of the transform that is applied to transform points from the coordinate system of the parent transform node.

parameter.label: Transform Matrix
parameter.description: 4x4 matrix. Each element is editable on double click. Type Enter to validate change, Escape to cancel or Tab to edit the next element.

parameter.label: Translation
parameter.description: Apply LR, PA, and IS translational components of the transformation matrix in the RAS space (in mm). Min and Max control the lower and upper bounds of the sliders.

parameter.label: Rotation
parameter.description: Apply LR, PA, and IS rotation angles (degrees) in the RAS space. Rotations are concatenated.

parameter.label: Coordinate Reference
parameter.description: Switches between global RAS space transformation and a local one, relative to the current position and orientation.

parameter.label: Identity
parameter.description: Resets transformation matrix to identity matrix.

parameter.label: Invert
parameter.description: Inverts the transformation matrix.

parameter.label: Visible in slice view
parameter.description: Show the transform in the slice viewers.

parameter.label: Visible in 3D view
parameter.description: Show the transform in the 3D viewers.

parameter.label: Region
parameter.description: Region where the transform is shown in the 3D view. It can be a slice viewer, volume, model, or a region of interest (ROI) node.

parameter.label: Visualization mode
parameter.description: Glyph: Show displacement at each point using an oriented scaled object. Grid: Show displacement as a deformed grid. Contour: Show isolines/isosurfaces corresponding to the specified displacement magnitudes.

parameter.label: Colors
parameter.description: Assign a color depending on the displacement magnitude.

parameter.label: Glyph mode: Spacing
parameter.description: Distance between glyphs.

parameter.label: Glyph mode: Scale factor
parameter.description: Percentage of displacement used for setting the glyph size. 100% means the glyph size equals the actual displacement. Does not affect coloring and visible range.

parameter.label: Glyph mode: Visible range
parameter.description: Only those glyphs are shown that have displacement magnitude within this range.

parameter.label: Glyph mode: Glyph type
parameter.description: Arrow: the arrow length and direction match the displacement vector (in 3D) or the displacement vector projection to the slice (in 2D) at the needle starting point. Cone: the cone length and direction match the the displacement vector (in 3D) or the displacement vector projection to the slice (in 2D) at the center of the cone. Sphere: the sphere/circle radius equals the displacement vector magnitude in the center of the sphere (same in 2D and 3D).

parameter.label: Grid mode: Spacing
parameter.description: Distance between the gridlines.

parameter.label: Grid mode: Scale factor
parameter.description: Percentage of displacement applied to the gridpoints. 100% means that the grid is deformed with the actual displacement.

parameter.label: Grid mode: Show original grid
parameter.description: Show non-warped grid in the slice view.

parameter.label: Grid mode: 3D gridline diameter
parameter.description: Thickness of the gridlines in the 3D view.

parameter.label: Grid mode: Resolution
parameter.description: Distance between sample points along the gridlines. Lower values result in gridlines that follow more closely the actual displacement vectors, but require more computation time.

parameter.label: Contour mode: Levels (mm)
parameter.description: Values defining the isolines and isosurfaces to contour. Values are separated by spaces.

parameter.label: Contour mode: 3D opacity
parameter.description: Opacity of the contour isosurfaces in the 3D view.

parameters.label: Transformed nodes
parameters.description: Control what nodes uses the current transformation.

parameter.label: Transformable
parameter.description: List the nodes in the scene that DON'T use the transform node.

parameter.label: Transformed
parameter.description: List the nodes in the scene that use the transform node.

parameter.label: Right arrow
parameter.description: Apply the current transform node to the selected nodes in Transformable list.

parameter.label: Left arrow
parameter.description: Remove the current transform node from the selected nodes in the Transformed list.

parameter.label: Harden transform
parameter.description: Apply the current transform node to the selected nodes in the Transformed list. This action moves the node back to the transformable lsit and "apply" the transform. It does, however, not resample the data, but rather place the information about the new orientation into the data header. When the data is saved, this information is saved also as part of the file header, as long as orientation data is supported by the file format. If the saved file is now loaded by another software that does not consider this header orientation (e.g. ImageJ) or does not visualize the data in physical space, then the data will appear in its old position. You can avoid this problem by actually resampling the data. To do this, go to the Resample module, and select your image and transform as input, create a new volume as output and click Apply. This new volume will now be in the new orientation that will be retained if saved and reloaded elsewhere.
